The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is an ___ year old woman who was found down in her 
home. Her landlord apparently found her on the floor in the 
apartment twice over the past 2 days. EMS arrived there today 
(unclear who called ___ and found very unsanitary living 
conditions. Her fingerstick was initially 128. She was brought 
to ___ ED.

In the ED, initial VS were 85.9 (rectal) 68 153/100 18 100% RA. 
Received 3L warm NS and placed on bear hugger. Labs were notable 
for WBC 13.2 (N 91.5%), Chem 7 unremarkable, ALT 42, AST 79, CK 
1041, APhos 144, Tbili 0.9, neg trop, lactate 1.5, neg UA, neg 
serum tox, neg Utox. CT Head notable for tiny calcification vs. 
hemorrhage. CT C-spine showed right clavicular fracture. CXR 
unremarkable. Pelvix XR showed possible left acetabulum 
fracture. Neurology was consulted with concern for altered 
mental status who suggested concern for infection, no evidence 
of stroke, less likely seizures. 

After rewarming, mental status improved. Bear hugger d/c'd in 
ED. ___ able to state that she has a neighbor ___ who 
helps buy her food/checks on her. She denied pain. She remembers 
falling off her couch at some point but is not sure why she's 
now in the hospital. 

Transfer VS were 96.8 68 109/43 18 100% RA.

On arrival to the floor, ___ is awake, alert, appropriate 
and answering questions. She reports recent coughing, sneezing, 
rhinorrhea x 1 week. She denies fevers, chills. 

___ neighbor) came to visit ___ on arrival to 
the floor. He reports that he found her on the ground a couple 
times in the last two days and was able to pick her up and get 
her back on her feet. ___ reports that he came to her 
apartment this morning as he usually does and she didn't respond 
to his hello. He turned on the lights and found her on the floor 
by the cough, arousable but lethargic and called EMS. ___ 
reports that she fell once before these events last ___ but 
doesn't know of other falls.

HEENT: R eye sclerotic/cloudy, left eye pupil reactive to light, 
EOMI, OP clear with poor dentition
CV: RRR, no m/r/g
PULM: CTAB anteriorly
AB: +BS, soft, non-distended/non-tender
EXT: many scrapes and bruises, WWP, toenails dystrophic 
NEURO: oriented to person, place and variably year but not month 
or date; moving all 4 extremities without limitation (no pain), 
good strength.
report:
ADDENDUM TO PRIOR REPORT 

Findings were discussed with Dr. ___ over the phone by Dr. ___
at 10:09 a.m. and the findings were made at 10 a.m. on the same day.
REASON FOR EXAMINATION:  Fall, new increasing oxygen requirement after fluid
resuscitation.

Portable AP radiograph of the chest was compared to ___.

Since the prior study, there is interval development of moderate-to-severe
pulmonary edema that might be related to the fluid resuscitation.  There are
bilateral pleural effusions present.  There is old fracture of the distal
right clavicle noted.
INDICATION:  Status post fall.  Evaluate for acute intracranial process or
fracture.

COMPARISON:  None.

TECHNIQUE:  Sequential axial images were acquired through the head without
administration of intravenous contrast material.  Multiplanar reformats were
performed.

IMPRESSION:

1.  4-mm hyperdense focus within the left internal capsule versus globus
pallidus internus, concerning for a tiny intraparenchymal hemorrhage. 
Alternatively, this could represent mineralization of the basal ganglia. 
Prior outside hospital comparison studies could be helpful for further
evaluation otherwise recommend follow up CT.

2.  No acute large vascular territorial infarction.
INDICATION:  Status post fall.  Assess for fracture or malalignment.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial images were acquired through the cervical spine without
administration of intravenous contrast material.  Multiplanar reformats were
performed.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION:

1.  No acute fracture in the cervical spine.  Loss of the normal cervical
lordosis is likely degenerative in nature.

2.  Slightly comminuted fracture through the proximal aspect of the right
clavicle with probable adjacent callus formation.  This fracture may be
subacute in nature, although correlation with physical exam is recommended.

3.  Multinodular thyroid could be further evaluated with ultrasound, if
clinically indicated.

4.  Secondary interlobular septal thickening in both lung apices, suggestive
of mild interstitial pulmonary edema.
HISTORY:  Status post fall.  Question acute cardiopulmonary process.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary process. Subacute appearing
fracture of the right distal clavicle. 

HISTORY:  Repeated falls.  Unable to provide history.

COMPARISON:  None.

The history of present illness : This is a ___ year old woman with history of hyperlipidemia, 
Graves' disease (S/P distant partial thyroidectomy) presenting 
with dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and palpitations, referred to ED 
with new, symptomatic atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular 
rate and dyspnea.
  The patient notes at least a week of DOE (with >1 city block, 
following smoking cessation) accompanied by worsening chest 
tightness and feelings of palpitations, orthopnea, and 
paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, but no lower extremity edema or 
weight gain. She does note that she snores at baseline and often 
wakes up tired in the morning.
  On outpatient evaluation, VR 140s-160s, SaO2 99% on O2 2 Lpm, 
BP 120s/80s. EKG with VR in the 130s, irregularly irregular, 
normal axis. She was referred to the ED.
  In the ED, initial vital signs were Pulse 70 BP 123/87 RR 20 
SaO2 100% on RA. Labs were notable for NT-Pro-BNP 3308, Trop-T 
<0.01, negative UA. TSH 2.2. CXR showed mild pulmonary edema. 
EKG showing atrial fibrillation with RVR rate 158, possible LVH. 
ED course complicated by VR as fast as 168 ___s flash 
pulmonary edema after receiving NS 1 L, so was given 
nitroglycerin sl, furosemide 20 mg IV, and started on BiPAP ___ 
with 100% FiO2. She improved with BiPap and diuresis and was 
transitioned to O2 3 lpm via NC. She also received ASA 324 mg, 
diltiazem 10 mg IV x3, and 30 mg PO x2, enoxaparin. Vitals prior 
to transfer were VR 89 BP 110/75 RR 28 SaO2 97% on RA.
  Upon arrival to the cardiology ward, the patient felt that her 
dyspnea was much improved.

carcinoma s/p lumpectomy, as well as HTN and venous statsis who

unresponsive on scene.

As per ER report and grandson, patient was in her usual state of
health until yesterday with no focal deficits. This am, woke up,
seen well by her daughter, and then went to bathroom. A little
later, daughter heard a "thud" and went to the bathroom where 
she
found the patient down, unresponsive. EMS was called, and she 
was
intubated on site and brought to ___ ER.

On arrival, SBP noted to be in 200s. Patient unresponsive.
Initially noted to be flaccid, but then posturing. CT head was
done which showed a large, right sided intraparenchymal bleed
with intraventricular extension with leftward subfalcine
herniation and downward transtentorial herniation . Neurosurgery
was consulted who do not think surgical intervention is 
indicated
at this time. Placed on nicardipine drip and given Mannitol 40g
IV X1.

The history of present illness : ___ with hx of IDDM, ESRD on PD, CAD, sCHF (EF 40%) who 
presented with unresponsiveness ___ hypoglycemia.  
 The patient has ESRD and is undergoing renal tranplantation 
workup. He had an outpatient abd/pelvic MRI to evaluate existing 
RP, pelvic, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. His morning blood 
sugar was 250. He took 7 units of lantus and 3 units of novolog 
per sliding scale. He was told not to eat lunch given the MRI. 
However, at noon his BS was 48 so he had a glass of sugar water. 
When he presented to the MRI holding area he felt weak, 
consistent with hypoglycemia. He had the MRI tech give him 
juice. However, after the MRI he was found acutely altered and 
unresponsive. A code was called. There was concern for possible 
seizure activity with lip smaking. His vital signs were stable 
and he had a pulse; was satting 100% RA and protecting airway. 
His initial fingerstick <20. Ativan 1mg IM given in right thigh 
given seizure concern. A left IO was placed. 1 amp of D50 pushed 
through IO and the patient immediately woke up, yelling of pain. 
Lidocaine IV given through IO. Repeat fingerstick 145. He was 
transported to ED alert and oriented.  
 In the ED, initial vitals were: 97.1 73 174/99 14 100% RA  
 - Labs were significant for improved anemia, BUN 60, creatinine 
11.8, normal lactate.  
 - FSG initially 65, but then remained in the mid ___ 200s 
in the ED.  
 - No imaging performed  
 - The patient was given:  
 
 IV Dextrose 50% 25 gm  
 IVF 1000 mL D10W 100 mL/hr  
 IV Morphine Sulfate 5 mg ___  
 
 Vitals prior to transfer were: 96.9 87 135/67 13 100% RA  
 Upon arrival to the floor, the patient still feels weak. Mild 
pain at the left lower extremity where the IO was placed. Denies 
other complaints.

In the ED, vitals initially were 97.6, 101/74, 72, 97% 2L. Pt 
desatted to 89% on RA.  Labs remarkable for Cr of 2.1, BUN 57, 
ALP 435, AST 47, Hgb 12.5, Hct 38, INR 1.3. Lipase was 44. CXR 
showed interval development of mild pulmonary edema and likely 
increase in size of moderate sized loculated pleural effusion on 
the right.  New small left pleural effusion. Elevation in LFTs 
in the setting of RUQ abd pain concerning for gallbladder 
pathology. RUQ U/S negative for cholecystitis but did show mild 
to moderate ascites. EKG ___ PR prolongation (~240ms). 

Vitals at the time of transfer were 98.9, 106/79, 77, 18, 95% 
2L.

On the floor, continues to report RUQ abdominal pain along with 
some RLQ pain and overall describes his abdomen as stiff.  He 
has not vomited since arriving at ___ but does occasionally 
have a cough which is productive of small amounts of yellow 
sputum which can be seen in the basin at the bedside. Cough 
sounds very wet. Vitals were 97.7, 105/73, 77, 20, 95% 2L. He 
denies fever, chills, SOB, CP, N/V/D. 

Review of Systems:  
(+) as in HPI  
(-) fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes,

right-sided pleural effusion and failed talc pleurodesis.  Patient now
experiencing worsening dyspnea and has Pleurx catheter in place.  Reevaluation
of pleural effusion.

abdomen without intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformations were
prepared.

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior CT chest from ___ to ___.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Overall stable multiloculated right pleural effusion compared to ___, despite Pleurx drainage cathether traversing large components of pleural
fluid collections.
2.  Unchanged narrowing of the bronchus intermedius and occlusion of the lower
lobe bronchus by hilar lymphadenopathy.
3.  Mildly increased non-hemorrhagic left pleural effusion.
4.  Low volume ascites, increased from ___.
TYPE OF EXAMINATION:  Chest AP portable single view.

INDICATION:  ___ male patient with pleural effusions and chronic
PleurX catheter line, status post TPA administration.  Evaluate for possible
pneumothorax or change in effusion.

FINDINGS:  AP single view of the chest has been obtained with patient in
semi-upright position.  Analysis is performed in direct comparison with the
next preceding similar study of ___.  There is no evidence of
pneumothorax on either side which can be identified with this portable single
view examination.  Comparison with the next previous study suggests that the
right-sided massive pleural densities have changed in position slightly and as
much, there is improved aeration of the right upper lobe area and the
previously identified large pleural density in the right axillary area
impressing on the aerated lung tissue has clearly decreased.  On the other
hand, it is impossible to assess whether the loculated pleural effusion has
shifted more to the lower areas.  Again, portable chest examination does not
allow assessment of the right-sided subhilar and parenchymal abnormalities. 
No new abnormalities are identified in the left hemithorax as there was no
repeat lateral view, one cannot comment on the amount of pleural effusion on
the left side identified on the preceding study.  The draining PleurX catheter
remains in place.

report:
EXAMINATION:  ABDOMEN (SUPINE AND ERECT) PORT

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with intermittent fevers, abdominal guarding  //
R/O perforation, ileus

TECHNIQUE:  KUB and upright.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION: 

Ileus.
EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with thalamic hemorrhage and massive midbrain
AVM, now with increased confusion and somnolence. Evaluate for extension of
bleed and hydrocephalus.

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the brain were obtained without
contrast.

DOSE:  DLP:  897 mGy-cm
CTDI:  53 mGy

COMPARISON:  CT from ___ and MR from ___.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  Stable left intraparenchymal hemorrhage centered around the left basal
ganglia and internal capsule.
2.  Small amount of intraventricular hemorrhage extension with stable
ventricle size.
3.  Right paranasal sinus disease.
EXAMINATION:  BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with recurrent fevers, not on prophylactic
heparin due to intracranial hemorrhage  // ? DVTs

TECHNIQUE:  Grey scale, color, and spectral Doppler evaluation was performed
on the bilateral lower extremity veins.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION: 

No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the bilateral lower extremity veins.
EXAMINATION:  L-SPINE (AP AND LAT) IN O.R.

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with back pain  // eval

TECHNIQUE:  Frontal and lateral projections of the lumbar spine for a total of
two images.

COMPARISON:   None.

IMPRESSION: 

Limited evaluation on the lateral projection.

Possible cortical contour abnormality along the anterior aspect of L2,
difficult to exclude fracture. Given limitation of current radiographic
series, repeat lateral view may assist, alternatively further assessment with
cross-sectional imaging can be performed.

Mild to moderate multilevel degenerative disc disease most pronounced at
L3-L4.

___ at 09:57 into the Department of Radiology critical communications
system for direct communication to the referring provider.
EXAMINATION:  CT L-SPINE W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old male with history of large superior midbrain and

hemorrhage, now with back pain and recent lumbar spine x-ray questioning L2
vertebral body anterior wedge compression deformity.  Evaluate for possible L2

CTDIvol:  11.7 mGy
DLP:  262 mGy-cm

COMPARISON:  Lumbar x-ray, ___.

IMPRESSION:


1. No evidence of lumbar spinal fracture.
2. Degenerative changes of the lumbar spine, as described above.
EXAMINATION:  CHEST RADIOGRAPHS

INDICATION:  Thalamic bleed. Fever.

TECHNIQUE:  Chest, AP upright and lateral.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION:

parenchymal reaction which may indicate that the lesion is posttraumatic but
the possibility of soft tissue mass should be considered.

Initial further evaluation with dedicated left rib radiographs is suggested.
EXAMINATION:  CTA HEAD AND CTA NECK

INDICATION:  History: ___ with L thalamic/ventricular bleed  // Evidence of
vascular abnormlaity

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain without
contrast material. Subsequently, rapid axial imaging was performed from the
aortic arch through the brain during infusion of Omnipaque intravenous
contrast material. Three-dimensional angiographic volume rendered, curved
reformatted and segmented images were generated. This report is based on
interpretation of all of these images.
EXAMINATION:  MR HEAD W AND W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with IPH and IVH  // ? progression of bleed,
underlying etiology

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal and axial T1 weighted imaging were performed. After
administration of 6cc of Gadavist intravenous contrast, axial imaging was
performed with gradient echo, FLAIR, diffusion, and T1 technique. Sagittal
MPRAGE imaging was performed and re-formatted in axial and coronal
orientations. Coronal T1 pre and coronal T1 fat saturation post contrast
sequences were also performed to evaluate sinus disease.

COMPARISON:  Noncontrast CT head, CTA head ___

IMPRESSION:


1. 6 cm diffuse arteriovenous malformation involving  the superior midbrain
and bilateral thalami with drainage into both the deep and superficial venous
systems via a persistent falcine sinus.
2. Intraventricular hemorrhage with a hematoma in the left basal ganglia and
extensive intraventricular hemorrhage are unchanged from CT earlier the same
day. Moderate dilatation of the ventricles appears to be due primarily to
underlying parenchymal volume loss as sulci and cisterns are prominent and
there is no evidence of transependymal flow of CSF.
3. Right-sided paranasal sinus disease in a pattern suggesting obstruction of
the middle meatus.  There is low signal intensity lesion seen extending from
right maxillary sinus to nasal passage which can be a mass or a polyp. 
Correlation with direct visualization may help for further assessment. .
EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with IPH/IVH  // ? progression of bleed,
hydrocephalus; please do morning of ___

contrast. Coronal and sagittal as well as thin bone-algorithm reconstructed
images were obtained.

DOSE:  DLP:  892 mGy-cm
CTDI:  55 mGy

COMPARISON:  Outside noncontrast head CT dated ___.  CTA of the head
neck performed earlier the same day.

IMPRESSION: 

1. Similar extent of intraparenchymal hemorrhage centered in the left basal
ganglia with large component of intraventricular hemorrhage.
2. Unchanged size and configuration of the ventricles.
3. Known large arteriovenous malformation centered in the mid brain is better
assessed on the preceding CTA.
4. Masslike soft tissue protuberances arising from the right maxillary sinus
extending into the right nasal passageway is incompletely evaluated.
EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with large midbrain AVM, s/p bleed. Evaluate for
interval change. Evaluate for hydrocephalus.

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the brain were obtained without
contrast.  Thin bone-algorithm reconstructed images were obtained.

DOSE:  DLP: 897 mGy-cm
CTDI: 54 mGy

COMPARISON:  Head CT dated ___.

IMPRESSION: 

1. No significant interval change in left basal ganglia intraparenchymal
hemorrhage with intraventricular extension and surrounding edema.

2. Stable ventricular size and configuration.

3. Right paranasal sinus disease unchanged.
EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with avm and intracranial bleed.  now febrile. 
// eval for pna      eval for pna

IMPRESSION: 

In comparison with the study of ___, there is enlargement of the cardiac
silhouette with left ventricular configuration. No evidence of acute

patient permits, a lateral view would better evaluate the region behind the
cardiac silhouette.

and frequently short of breath. She reports diffuse body pain 
that comes and goes, as well as chills. She also says that she 
has had poor PO intake and no appetite since her gastric bypass 
surgery in ___. Denies fevers, falls/ injuries, abdominal pain, 
urinary symptoms, diarrhea, nausea or vomitting.  Reports she 
was seen for these symptoms at ___, given Lasix, however she 
does not want to take Lasix. Of note, patient had multiple 
abdominal surgeries one year ago, had poor recovery, reports not 
feeling well since then. 

Records from ___ ___ indicate the patient was admitted for a 
similar reason. She was complaining of painful bilateral lower 
extremity edema, and was found to be severely malnourished with 
a low albumin. 
  
In the ED, initial vital signs were: 100.9 113 115/70 20 100%RA
  
ED Exam notable for

The history of present illness : ___ year old male with h/o HIV/AIDS (last CD4 344 ___ ___ and 
severe COPD (home ___, FEV1 is 13% of predicted) admitted 
to the ICU with hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient's history was gathered via ED documentation and his 
home caretaker. According to the patient's caretake, the patient 
was ___ his usual state of health on the morning/afternoon prior 
to presentation. He did not note any ILI symptoms, including no 
fever, chills, cough, sputum production or chest pain. On the 
evening prior to presentation, the patient was noted to be more 
somnolent than is typical for him, at times he was difficult to 
arouse. EMS was called for this concern, and the patient was 
noted to be tachypneic at the time. The patient endorsed feeling 
short of breath, and was speaking ___ ___ word sentences. He was 
subsequently transferred to the ED.    

Of note, the patient was recently admitted to ___ from 
___ after presenting with similar symptoms. At that 
time, his symptoms were refarctory to outpatient steroids, and 
improved ___ house with steroids, nebulizers, and initiation of 
levofloxacin. The patient discharged on levofloxacin x 5 days 
and 12 day prednisone taper starting at 80mg daily. On ___, 
the patient saw Dr. ___ ___ outpatient clinic, and remained 
short of breath, wheezing and not quite back to his baseline per 
clinic notes. 
  
___ the ED, initial vs were: 101 160/95 32 96%. Labs were 
significant for WBC 3.9, bicarb 42, and lactate 0.7. UA was 
negative. Initial ABG showed pH 7.29 pCO2 103 pO2 142. He was 
placed on BiPAP. EKG showed sinus rhythm with rate 96 and poor 
R-wave progression. CXR showed mild pulmonary vascular 
engorgement and r-demonstration of indistinct right upper lobe 
opacity for which a chest CT was again recommended to exclude 
malignancy. Patient was given vancomycin 1 g IV, levofloxacin 
750 mg IV, and cefepime 2 g IV X 1. He was given albuterol and 
ipratropium nebs, methyprednisolone 125 mg X 1, and azithromycin 
500 mg X 1. The patient was intubated prior to transfer given 
worsening somnolence. VS on transfer:  105 133/82 30 100%

CHEST ON ___

The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is a ___ with PMH of HTN, HLD, tobacco use, who 
presented to OSH w/ CP and was found to have a NSTEMI so was 
transferred to ___ for PCI.

Pt reported that she was not feeling herself for the past wk. OF 
note, she ran out of Anti-HTN 2 wks ago. Then on ___, she awoke 
from sleep with sharp chest pain, felt in sternum and L breast, 
radiating to L arm, ___ in intensity, waxing/waning, lasting 
up to 5min at ___ that was a/w nausea, diaphoresis, 
lightheadedness/dizziness, palpitations and shortness of breath. 
At 5am that morning, she could no longer tolerate the pain and 
was BIBEMS (and received ASA325) to ___ ED for 
evaluation.

At the outside hospital, she was found to be hemodynamically 
stable with no evidence of ischemic EKG changes, but TnI of 
0.64, AST of 39. CXR was reportedly unremarkable. Heparin (bolus 
+ drip) and nitroglycerin drips were initiated prior to 
transfer. Pt reported that her CP decreased to ___ intensity 
s/p nitroglycerin, and remained at that level prior to transfer.

In the ED, initial vitals were as follows: 97.3, 57, 144/87, 18, 
96% RA. Admission labs were notable for unremarkable Chem10, 
CBC, and coagulation panel and TnT of 0.22. Heparin and 
nitroglycerin drips were continued. She received morphine 5mg x1 
for refractory chest pain. She received atorvastatin 80mg and 
was loaded with clopidogrel 600mg. Vital signs prior to transfer

The history of present illness : ___ with a history of HFpED (EF 55-60%), CKD, hypertension,
hyperlipidemia, type II diabetes mellitus, morbid obesity, COPD,
and suspected OSA/OHS, who initially presented to ___ with
shortness of breath and lower extremity edema in the setting of
an heart failure exacerbation, now transferred to CCU following
episode of acute hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
intubation.

Patient initially presented on ___ in the setting of several
weeks of progressive weight gain, scrotal edema, and lower
extremity edema, despite escalation in home dose of torsemide
from 80mg BID to ___ BID, in addition to intermittent dosing 
of
metolozone 2.5mg. NT-proBNP was only mildly elevated at 772,
although this is in the setting of morbid obesity, with
associated troponin-T elevation to 0.07-0.08. CXR demonstrated
pulmonary edema, which was worse when compared to prior. He was
diuresed aggressively with IV furosemide 120-160mg daily to BID
since admission with significant output. Given difficult volume
status examination, it was determined he was
hypovolemic-euvolemic as of ___ AM by lab evaluation
(increasing creatinine), at which time he was transitioned to PO
torsemide 100mg BID. Hospitalization also notable for ___ on CKD
felt likely secondary to renal congestion in setting of
cardiorenal syndrome, nighttime hypoxia felt secondary to
undiagnosed OSA, and intermittent agitation and aggression
towards staff members. Podiatry had also evaluated the patient
for bilateral heel ulcers and deemed no surgical intervention or
debridement necessary during this admission. 

Overnight ___, patient was triggered for increasing
hypoxia (O2 saturation in ___ with associated somnolence. Upon
evaluation by the medicine team on the floor, he was noted to be
somnolent, only opening his eyes intermittently to voice, but 
not
following commands. Initially placed on face mask with 
persistent
O2 saturation of 40-60s, with good oxygen pleth per report.
Transitioned to a non-rebreather with improvement in O2
saturation to 70-80s, however only transient with subsequent 
drop
again to 40-60s. Unclear how good oxygen pleth was at that time.
CODE BLUE was called given concern for impending respiratory
collapse and need for intubation. Radial pulse was strong
throughout. Decision was made, in conjunction with anesthesia, 
to
intubate at the bedside, and transfer to CCU. Patient was given
IV furosemide 160mg prior to transfer. 

Upon arrival to the CCU, patient is intubated and sedated, as
such is unable to provide further history.

elevated, VBG pH fo 7.17, Glucose >700, started on insulin gtt

another 2L in the ED here. She is moaning and sleepy. On ___ 
liter of fluid coming from ED and still looks dry. Pinkish 
tinged stool, started on pantoprazole 40 mg IV in ED. Vanc given 
at ___. R femoral line and two peripherals in place.

At ___, labs showed WBC of 24.6, Hb of 15.2, Hct of 48.8, Na

0.9, AST 206, ALT 119, Alk P ___, Alb 3.9, VBG pH 7.178, CO2

On arrival to the ICU, patient was tachypneic to 44, drowsy,

FLUOROSCOPY TIME AND DOSE: 7 seconds, 3 mGy

PROCEDURE:  1. Repositioning of left arm approach PICC.

PROCEDURE DETAILS: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the existing
PICC line was aspirated and flushed and a standard 0.018 guidewire was
introduced into the superior vena cava (SVC). The malpositioned left approach
PICC line was withdrawn and a peel-away sheath was then placed over the
guidewire. The guidewire was then advanced into the superior vena cava. A
double lumen PIC line measuring 41 cm in length was then placed through the
peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the distal SVC under fluoroscopic
guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film
of the chest. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The
catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
complications.

IMPRESSION: 

Successful placement of a 41 cm left arm approach double lumen PICC with tip
in the distal SVC. The line is ready to use.

who is brought in by her son and daughter-in-law with persistent

diarrhea and hit her head on the door while walking to the
bathroom. She was hospitalized at ___ where
they found an abnormality on a scan of her head. To his 
knowledge
she was not treated for an infection at that time and discharged
on ___. When he went to get her from ___ he noted her
memory was worse and she was not as communicative as she 
normally
is and although she was not complaining of anything she was
persistently febrile so he brought her to the emergency
department.  
 
Review of OSH records ___ ___:
Presented to their ED with n/v x 3d and fall onvernight with
resultant facial bruising, noted to be hyponatremic (serum Na
107, felt to be related to hypovolemia, chlorthalidone, and head
injury) without neurologic sequelae, admitted to ICU there. 

Discharge labs ___ BMP
133/4.0 | ___ | ___ < 177 Ca 9.5 Mg 2.0 Phos 3.6

In the ED initial vitals were temp 97.7, heart rate 72, blood
pressure 120/51, respiratory rate 18, 98% on room air. However 4
hours after triage she spiked a temperature to 103.0 that was
confirmed rectally and became tachycardic to 107. On initial
evaluation the patient was not in distress but endorsed dysuria
and responded one-word answers. She is alert but oriented only 
to
self. The only notable finding on exam was fading bilateral
orbital ecchymoses.  
 
Labs were notable for hyponatremia with a sodium of 123,
leukocytosis to 19.3 and mild anemia at 10.9 and 32.2 she also
had a grossly positive UA.  

She was given:  
___ 06:08 IVF 1L LR with maintenance LR at 150cc/hr.  
___ 06:14 IV Ketorolac 15 mg  
___ 06:43 IV CefTAZidime 1 g  
___ 08:46 SC Insulin 4 Units  
___ 08:54 IV Vancomycin 750 mg (___)  
___ 09:52 PO Acetaminophen 1000 mg  
___ 14:38 SC Insulin 6 Units  

CT head was notable for: A 5 x 4.5 x 3.5 cm hypodense cystic 
(CSF
density) lesion at the cerebral midline (between the lat
ventricles) is most consistent with a prominent cavum velum
interpositum (a developmental anomaly). 

NCHCT from previous admission at ___:
No acute intraparenchymal findings. Ventriculomegaly at least in
part due to the presence of a 6 cm arachnoid cyst. Further
evaluation with MRI is warranted. Periventricular low 
attenuation
which could have several possible etiologies including chronic
microangiopathic process or less likely transependymal flow of
CSF. Cortical sulcal prominence. 

CXR read as "No pneumonia. Possible, acute bronchitis." 

She was admitted to medicine for further workup.  

Upon arrival to the floor, patient seen and evaluated at bedside
by the ___ team with the help of ___ language
interpreter ___. Two of her sons, her daughter-in-law, and
two grandsons were at the bedside. Patient stated she was 
feeling
well without complaints. She was oriented to person and place 
but
not to time. She could not explain why she was in the hospital.

The history of present illness : ___ year old male with recent diagnosis of stage IV colonic 
adenocarcinoma, DM II, HL and HTN presenting with RLQ and right 
flank pain.  He was discharged on ___ after being diagnosed 
with stage IV colon cancer with large nearly obstructing sigmoid 
mass with metastatic disease to the liver.  Decision was made 
not to pursue primary resection as clinically he did not have 
symptoms of obstruction.  Plan was for outpatient follow-up at 
___ with Dr. ___ to discuss starting chemotherapy.  
He also was found to have a pan-sensitive klebsiella UTI and was 
symptomatic with dysuria, he was given a 5 day course of IV 
ceftriaxone. and reports dysuria resolved.  He denies having 
significant issues with abdominal or flank pain during 
admission.  He was discharged on ___ and reports he was doing 
well until yesterday in the mid-day he began having sharp, 
intermittent RLQ and right flank pain, nausea, vomiting, chills 
and recurrent dysuria.  Reports last BM was two days ago and was 
normal, solid and brown without blood.  Denies diarrhea.  Denies 
hematuria.  He presented to ___, had a CT scan there 
with wet-read concerning for possible appendicitis and abscess 
as well as right hydronephrosis, urinalysis was grossly 
inflammatory, he was given Zosyn and transferred to ___ ED.

In ___ ED colorectal surgery and urology were consulted.  They 
reviewed his CT scan and felt it was not significantly changed 
from prior CT on ___.  Colorectal surgery recommended placing 
him on cipro/flagyl.  Given the recurrent urinary tract 
infection and persistent hydronephrosis urology recommend ___ 
consult for a right percutaneous nephrostomy tube.  

Currently he reports that his pain is mild after receiving IV 
dilaudid.  Still feeling nauseous.  Passing gas but no BM in 2 
days.  Denies headache, cough, SOB, CP, leg swelling, rash.

report:
INDICATION:  ___ year old man with metastatic colon cancer with right
hydronephrosis and recurrent urinary tract infection.  Right percutaneous
nephrostomy tube placement.

COMPARISON:  Outside CT abdomen dated ___.

TECHNIQUE:  OPERATORS: Dr. ___ and Dr.
___ radiologist performed the procedure. Dr. ___
___ supervised the trainee during the key components of the procedure
and has reviewed and agrees with the trainee's findings.
ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administrating divided doses of
150 mcg of fentanyl and 4 mg of midazolam throughout the total intra-service
time of 30 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were
continuously monitored by an independent trained radiology nurse. 1% lidocaine
was injected in the skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the access site.
MEDICATIONS:  Versed, Fentanyl, 1% lidocaine
CONTRAST: 15 ml of Optiray contrast.
FLUOROSCOPY TIME AND DOSE:  6.3 min, 69 mGy

PROCEDURE:  1. Right ultrasound guided renal collecting system access.
2. Right nephrostogram.
3.  Right ___ nephrostomy tube placement.

PROCEDURE DETAILS: Following the discussion of the risks, benefits and
alternatives to the procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the
patient. The patient was then brought to the angiography suite and placed
prone on the exam table.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed per ___
protocol. The right flank was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.

After the injection of 5 cc of 1% lidocaine in the subcutaneous soft tissues,
the right renal collecting system was accessed through a posterior lower pole
calyx under ultrasound guidance using a 21 gauge Cook needle. Ultrasound
images of the access were stored on PACS. Prompt return of urine confirmed
appropriate positioning. Injection of a small amount of contrast outlined a
dilated renal collecting system.

Under fluoroscopic guidance, a Nitinol wire was advanced into the renal
collecting system. After a skin ___, the needle was exchanged for an
Accustick sheath. Once the tip of the sheath was in the collecting system; the
sheath was advanced over the wire, inner dilator and metallic stiffener. The
wire and inner dilator were then removed and diluted contrast was injected
into the collecting system to confirm position.

A ___ wire was advanced through the sheath and ___ and ___ serial dilation was
performed.  Due to kinking of the wire, the ___ wire was replaced by an
Amplatz wire. The sheath was then removed and a 8 ___ nephrostomy tube was
advanced into the renal collecting system. The wire was then removed and the
pigtail was formed in the collecting system. Contrast injection confirmed
appropriate positioning. The catheter was then flushed, ___ silk stay sutures
applied and the catheter was secured with a Stat Lock device and sterile
dressings. The catheter was attached to a bag.

IMPRESSION: 

Successful placement of 8 ___ nephrostomy on the right.  The catheter was
attached to a bag.

report:
EXAM:  Chest frontal and lateral views.

CLINICAL INFORMATION:  Dyspnea, lower extremity edema, crackles on exam.

COMPARISON  ___.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Mild vascular congestion.
2.  More focal opacity at the right lung base which may relate to vascular
congestion, although consolidation is not excluded in the appropriate clinical
setting.
HISTORY:  Fracture followup.

Three views of the left wrist show a healed fracture of the distal radial
metaphysis with the distal radial articular surface perpendicular to the
radial shaft in lateral projection.  There is an ununited fracture of the base
of the ulnar styloid.  Vascular calcifications.  There is post-fracture slight
positive ulnar variance.  Since exam ___, the radial fracture lines
are no longer identified.
HISTORY:  History of Clostridium difficile, presents with new lower abdominal
pain.  Assess fecal load, obstruction, ileus.

COMPARISON:  Abdominal radiograph, ___ CT abdomen/pelvis, ___.

IMPRESSION:  Nonobstructive bowel gas pattern.  No secondary signs of free
intraperitoneal air.
ABDOMEN AND PELVIC CT WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with LLQ pain and history of C Difficile. 
Evaluate for diverticulitis.

___

TECHNIQUE:  CT of the abdomen and pelvis without IV contrast due to patient's
renal dysfunction. Oral contrast was administered.

CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST.  

There is bibasilar atelectasis. There is mild cardiomegaly. Cardiac pacemaker
leads are partially imaged. There is marked atherosclerosis of the visualized
thoracic aorta.

The liver demonstrates a normal unenhanced appearance.  The spleen, pancreas,
gallbladder, the adrenal glands, and bowel are unremarkable. There is no
definite bowel wall thickening, no pericolonic fat stranding and no fluid
collections.  Mild diverticulosis. The left kidney is diminished in size. 
There are bilateral renal masses seen, which are incompletely evaluated given
the noncontrast technique.  There is no free interperitoneal air or free
fluid. 

There is mild diastasis of the superior rectus abdominis muscles with
extrusion of some fat at the level of the upper abdomen.  There is also a
small fat containing paraumbilical hernia.  Both of these abdominal wall
defects appear unchanged since ___.

Subcutaneous injection sites are noted in the subcutaneous tissues of the
abdomen.

CT OF THE PELVIS WITHOUT IV CONTRAST.  The uterus and adnexa are grossly
normal.  There is no pelvic free fluid. There is a Foley catheter within the
urinary bladder.

BONE WINDOWS:  There are multilevel degenerative changes with no suspicious
osseous lesions.

There is extensive aortoiliac atherosclerosis present.  

High density focus in the region of the right gluteus musculature may
represent metastatic calcification from renal disease.

IMPRESSION:  

1. This examination is limited in ability to evaluate for diverticulitis given
the noncontrast technique, however there are no secondary signs of that
diagnosis. 

2. No cause for left lower quadrant pain is identified.

3. Bilateral renal masses are incompletely evaluated given the noncontrast
technique.  Recommend renal ultrasound for further evaluation.

These findings and recommendations were discussed with Dr. ___ by Dr.
___ at 6:03pm on ___.
INDICATION:  History of bilateral renal artery stenosis, now with worsening
chronic kidney disease and bilateral renal masses on recent CT, here for
further characterization of renal lesion.

COMPARISON:  Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis dated ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Grayscale and limited Doppler ultrasound images of the kidneys
were obtained.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Bilateral simple-to mildly complex renal cysts corresponding to renal
lesions seen on recent CT. No concerning renal lesion is seen.
2.  Although a complete renal Doppler study was not performed, the bilateral
main renal artery and vein are grossly patent.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : Mr. ___ is an ___ year old right handed man with history of
questionable thalamic infarct (___), transient global
amnesia,  left carotid dissection with pseudoaneurysm, complex
partial seizures who was unsteady and "spacey" this morning, was
found to have a right temporo-parietal intraparenchymal 
hemorrhage at ___ and is
transferred here for further care.  Yesterday evening, patient
was in his usual state of health.  Mr. ___ was awakened 
this
morning at approximately 7am to take his pills at his assisted
living facility.  The woman who gave him his medications thought
he was "a bit unsteady."  Patient did acknowledge that when
walking, he was bumping into things more than usual with his
hips, unsure right or left.  He also felt a little bit spacey 
and
disoriented.  He did not notice any vision changes until he was
directly tested.  Denies focal weakness or numbness, no
dizziness/lightheadedness, speech difficulty.  Does endorse
sharp, right fronto-parietal region headaches that have occured
~3 times in the last week and lasted seconds.  Patient went to
have breakfast where 2 people asked him if he was okay.  So, he
was brought to the nurse at the facility for evaluation.  She 
was
concerned and called an ambulance to take him to ___.   There, 
a
___ showed an intraparenchymal hemorrhage involving right
temporo-parietal region with surrounding edema, no midline 
shift.
Patient denies any recent fall/trauma.  His daughter notes that
on ___, his walking seemed a little bit unsteady and 
___
He used  to have a diagnosis of hypertension, but had not been 
on
medications for some time.  Most recent colonoscopy in ___ was
normal.  Denies constitutional symptpoms.  Of note, patient was
admtitted to ___ in ___ at which time he had an MRI brain 
w/
and w/o contrast which showed a heterogeneously enhancing
pituitary gland, differential including vs. adenoma.  

Mr. ___ was hospitalized at ___ ~6
weeks ago per patient and family. He had an episode of tingling
in the left finger tips/tongue, left facial drop, dysarthria 
that
waxed and waned for ___ minutes.  It was thought that this
episode was as seizure.  His Keppra dose was increased.  Then,
after discharge, the dose was decreased.  Shortly thereater,
patient had "2 more seizures," details not clear and Keppra was
once again increased.  1 week ago, patient was also started on
Lamictal. In regards to his seizure disorder, the details are 
not
quite clear.  The first episode was ___ years ago.  Mr. 
___
had a family party and made a cake which he brought.  When he 
was
there, he seemed to have "lost time" and did not even remember
making the cake.  Per daughter, he was diagnosed with temporal
lobe seizures at that time (unsure about EEGs done) and was
started on Keppra.  He has been on that since with good control.

Mr. ___ was also hospitalized in ___ at ___ with an
episode of tingling in his left 3 middle fingers and admitted 
for
TIA work up.  He was evaluated  by neurology who felt symptoms
were most likely peripheral.  An MRI brain and MRA ___ 
were
unrevealing. MRI C spine showed multi level spondylosis.  An EEG
was obtained as well which showed occasional focal slowing seen
over the left greater than right temporal leads suggestive of
subcortical dysfunction, no epileptiform discharges, unchanged
from ___.  A TTE showed EF 60-65%, no thrombus.       

On neuro ROS, the pt denies blurred vision, diplopia, 
dysarthria,
dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing
difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending
speech.  Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel
or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with
gait.
 
On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills.  No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies
cough, shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain or tightness,
palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation 
or
abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or bladder habits.  
No
dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

report:
HISTORY:  Intracerebral hemorrhage. Evaluate for pneumonia.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph 11:38 today.

FRONTAL AND LATERAL VIEWS OF THE CHEST:  There is no pleural effusion,
pneumothorax or focal airspace consolidation.  Heart size is top-normal and
unchanged.  The aorta is tortuous.

Advanced degenerative changes involve the left glenohumeral joint.

IMPRESSION: No change from 5 hours prior.

STUDY:  CTA of the head and CTA of the neck.

CLINICAL INDICATION:  ___ male patient with history of intracranial
hemorrhage, evaluate for intraparenchymal abnormality or aneurysm, mild
vascular malformation.

COMPARISON:  Head CT dated ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Axial MDCT images were obtained through the brain without
contrast.  After the administration of intravenous non-ionic contrast
material, rapid axial images were obtained from the aortic arch through the
head convexity, sagittal, coronal and axial reformations were provided.  On a
separate workstation, curved reformations and 3D rendering images were
obtained.

IMPRESSION:
1.  There is no significant change in the right parietal/temporal
intraparenchymal hematoma with mild associated edema and effacement of the
sulci.  There is no evidence of new hemorrhage.  There is no evidence of an
intracranial aneurysm or vascular malformation.
2.  The extracranial vessels again demonstrate a left internal carotid artery
pseudoaneurysm versus flap/dissection in the high cervical internal carotid
artery, likely chronic and demonstrated on the prior MRA of the neck on ___.  The neck vessels are patent with no evidence of critical stenosis.

A preliminary report was provided by Dr. ___ Dr. ___ discussed
with Dr. ___ at 5 p.m. on ___.
STUDY:  MRI of the head with and without contrast.

CLINICAL INDICATION:  ___ man with history of metastatic disease on
the pituitary region and intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right parietal and
right temporal lobe.

COMPARISON:  Prior CTA of the head and head CT dated ___. MRI
___.

TECHNIQUE:  Pre-contrast axial and sagittal T1-weighted images were obtained,
axial FLAIR, axial T2, axial magnetic susceptibility, and axial
diffusion-weighted sequences.  The T1-weighted images were repeated after the
administration of gadolinium contrast in axial T1, sagittal MP-RAGE and
multiplanar reconstructions were provided.

IMPRESSION: 1.  Heterogeneous intraparenchymal hematoma is redemonstrated in
the right temporal and right parietal lobes as described above, measuring
approximately 40 x 46 mm in transverse dimension, causing mild mass effect and
effacement of the sulci and right occipital ventricular horn, no evidence of
underlying lesions are identified, however, long-term followup is recommended
until complete resolution of the hematoma.

2.  Unchanged enlarged, heterogeneously enhancing pituitary gland. 
HISTORY:  Stroke with fever.

FINDINGS:  In comparison with the study of ___, there is little change and no
evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease.  Cardiac silhouette is mildly
enlarged and there is tortuosity of the aorta.  However, no acute pneumonia,
vascular congestion, or pleural effusion.
INDICATION:  History of right temporal intraparenchymal hemorrhage.  Please
evaluate for interval change.

COMPARISON:  PET-CT from ___.

TECHNIQUE:  ___ MDCT images were obtained through the brain without the
administration of IV contrast.  Multiplanar reformatted images in coronal and
sagittal axes were generated and reviewed.

IMPRESSION:  Overall stable right parietotemporal intraparenchymal hematoma
with mild associated edema and effacement of the sulci.  No new hemorrhage is
identified.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : ___ yo male with history of vasculitis, vitiligo, otherwise
healthy, presenting with subjective fevers and 1+ day of 
swelling
and pain in his left leg. 

Patient reports he is recently been in his usual state of 
health,
though due to work has spent a great deal of time outdoors
recently doing heavy manual labor. On ___ evening (___)
began to notice some swelling in his left calf, which he
initially attributed to dehydration.  He tried drinking a large
amount of water but ended up having episode of non-bloody,
bilious vomiting from this.  Yesterday (___) morning, he
began to notice several lesions on the left lower leg that
initially appeared like bug bites.  Lesions grew in size rapidly
and became confluent, itchy and painful.  He endorsed subjective
fevers, nausea and poor p.o. intake throughout the day yesterday
as well.  He was at work when his boss noticed his left leg
lesions and advised him to come into the ED for further
evaluation.

Patient reports having a very similar episode ___ years ago,
consisting of similar lesions in his legs that eventually
progressed to frank ulcers. He was treated at ___, diagnosed as
"vasculitis", though patient reports that much of his workup
there was negative.  Nevertheless, he reports being quite ill
from this, was placed on high-dose prednisone with a very long
taper over several months, and received aggressive wound care at
the time.  He recovered from this with no recurrence of the ___
lesions since then.

Additionally, pt has a different, papular rash over the dorsum 
of
his hands, R>L.  Is unclear exactly when this started but thinks
it was within the past week.  The rash seems to get worse with
exposure to direct sunlight.  The rash was also present on his
face earlier.  He denies any history of Raynaud's phenomenon

Lastly, patient endorses recent stomach upset, poor p.o. intake
and one episode of emesis 2 days ago after drinking a large
amount of water.  He denies any known history of ulcers or GI
bleeding, but notably he has been on high-dose naproxen 500 mg
BID for a long time, for various joint issues.  He notes that 
his
urine has been darker and foamy of late. 

On arrival to the ED pt was febrile to 101.0 and mildly
tachycardic. WBC 12.5 with 83% neutrophils, Cr 1.1. He received:
-IV clindamycin 600 mg
-1 L fluid bolus
-Zofran 4 mg IV
-GI cocktail 30 mg 1

The physical exam on admission : VITALS:
GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress, sitting up in bed, 
resp non labored
EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma.  

CV: Heart regular, no murmur, no S3, no S4.  No JVD.
RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement
bilaterally.  Breathing is non-labored
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation.  Bowel
sounds present.  No HSM
MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities, strength grossly full
and symmetric bilaterally in all limbs. No arthritic changes
SKIN: He has several confluent macular, violaceous, nonblanching
lesions that are confined to his left calf, present
circumferentially, but with a greater predominance anteriorly.
Warm, tender to palpation. Significant improvement in cellulitis 
boundaries from admission.
NEURO: CN2-12 grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficits
PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect
report:
EXAMINATION:  UNILAT LOWER EXT VEINS LEFT

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with recent history of erythema/warmth in LLE//
Hx of cellulitis and vasculitis, persistent pain in LLE, assess for DVT

TECHNIQUE:  Grey scale, color, and spectral Doppler evaluation was performed
on the left lower extremity veins.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION: 

No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity veins.
Incidental note is made of subcutaneous edema along the left lower extremity.
EXAMINATION:  CT LOWER EXT W/C LEFT

INDICATION:  ___ year old man presenting with LLE pain/cellulitis with prior
radiograph concerning for anterior fibular non-aggressive cortical lucency now
with pain and cellulitis

TECHNIQUE:  Contrast enhanced axial multidetector CT images from above the
knee through the left foot with coronal and sagittal reformations.

COMPARISON:  None

IMPRESSION:


1. Extensive circumferential subcutaneous edema, mild to moderate anterior
superficial fascial edema, and lower leg skin thickening is nonspecific but
consistent with cellulitis in the appropriate clinical context.  There is no
evidence of rim enhancing organized fluid collection to suggest abscess
formation.
2. Focal cortical thinning along the anterior aspect of the mid fibula appears
nonaggressive and may represent sequelae of prior trauma or a benign lesion
such as nonossifying fibroma.  Clinical correlation with prior x-rays
recommended to be the area seen on this exam correlates with finding on prior
radiograph.  This could likely be followed with radiographs if the findings
correlate.

The history of present illness : ___ yo M w/ h/o CAD, PAD, afib on warfarin, complete heart block 
s/p  PPM, HFrEF (LVEF= 40 % on ___, severe AS, DMII, 
vascular dementia presents from nursing home with fevers and 
altered mental status. Pt's wife provided history in ED, states 
that he has ulcer on left leg for days-weeks currently being 
treated with Bactrim. The left ulcer has been improving 
according to the patient's wife. This morning, his mental status 
became worse, and patient became sleepier and more confused than 
usual, also w/ fever up to 101 and chills. Per wife, patient has 
non-productive cough.  
 Patient was admitted to MICU in ___ for E. coli septicemia 
due to cholangitis and choledocholithiasis in the setting of 
significant stone burden in gallbladder and common bile duct s/p 
ERCP and treatment with Ceftriaxone.  
 
In the ED, initial vital signs were: T 98.4, HR 71, BP 109/46 RR 
20 Sat95% RA. T max was 102.7 and BP min was ___ which was 
responsive to 500mL NS Bolus  
 - Mental Status: alert, oriented to self  
 - Labs were notable for elevated WBC 11.6, Hg 13, platelets 
100, AST 44, Creatinine 2, elevated lactate 2.7 down to 2.1 
after fluids, and ___ 234. UA did not show signs of infection.  
 - Studies performed include blood cx, urine cx, ECG, CXR, ankle 
X-ray  
 - Patient was given Acetaminophen 1000 mg once, Vancomycin, 
Piperacillin-Tazobactam.  
 - Vitals on transfer: 99.6 72 137/45 18 94% RA  

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient was very tachypnic with a 
RR up to 38 per minutes. His oxygen sat was 88% on RA, 91% on 3 
L, then up to 98% with neb and 3 L. T was 99, HR 101, and SBP in 
120's. Patient was confused, alert and oriented to self only. No 
history can be obtained from patient. Floor team called wife who 
confirmed DNR/DNI status. ___ transferred to MICU on 
40% ___ satting mid ___. Had work of breathing. 
 
Review of Systems: Can not be obtained secondary to patient's 
mental status and respiratory distress.

The history of present illness : ___ F h/o pulmomary HTN, asthma, morbid obesity, OSA (home O2 at 
night, does not yet have CPAP) presents with SOB and hypoxemia 
from clinic. She was seen to follow up on daytime sleepiness and 
chronic headaches and was noted to have O2 sat 85% ra. Initial 
vital signs: HR-90-104 RR=20 BP 175/80. Pulmonary exam notable 
for diffuse wheze and diminshed breath sounds. She was given 1 
duoneb and her sat improbed to came up to 89 %. She desatted 
soon after to ___ and was placed on 3 L NC. Pt checks her sats 
at night and they can be as low as 79% on RA. She denies cough, 
fevers, chest pain. She has gained a significant amount of 
weight over the last several weeks. Admitted for abscess 
drained/hernia repair in ___. Per patient at that time her 
weight was 485 pounds; she is currently 19 lbs up from her dry 
weight. In addition she has noticed ___ edema and has a hard time 
wearing her shoes. She does not carry a formal dx of CHF however 
she was admitted later in ___ and was hypoxemic and volume 
overloaded (felt to be from too much IVF administration) and was 
diuresed. However, her chlorthalidone and lisinopril were held 
for the past couple of months because of ___. Verapamil 
increased recently for HTN. She is also trying to arrange to get 
a CPAP machine for home but hasn't gotten it yet due to 
logistical issues. 

In the ED initial vitals were: 97.8 80 154/86 20 91% 3L NC. Labs 
were significant for BNP 601 UA pos nitr, 19 blood, few bacteria 
(grew Klebsiella). CXR with pulmonary edema. Patient was given 
ceftriaxone for presumed UTI, lasix 40mg IV. Vitals prior to 
transfer were: 76 144/82 19 93% 2L NC.  On the floor she was in 
no distress and had no complaints. Review of systems were 
negative for fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision 
changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, chest pain, 
abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, 
melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.

time of this note.

available (and the voicemail was for a different person). Was 
told by neurosurgery that ___ who is patient's brother-in-law 
can be reached at ___, but that he would not be able to 
be in the hospital today.

IMPRESSION: 

Left basal ganglia hemorrhage with intraventricular extension appear similar
compared to most recent prior CT done, but appears improved compared to
initial CT as described above.  No underlying mass or vascular malformation. 
Imaging follow-up after complete resolution is advised to exclude an
underlying mass or vascular malformation with certainty.

The ventricular profile is stable and improved compared to initial CT.  Right
frontal approach external ventricular drain in situ.

There are multiple most subacute infarcts in the right basal ganglia and
thalamus as well as bilateral occipital and to a lesser degree the posterior
parietal and left frontal cortical gray matter as described above.  Infarcts
in various vascular territories suggest an embolic etiology.
Suspected chronic lacunar infarcts also noted in the midbrain bilateral.
Hemorrhagic transformation of a left basal ganglia infarct and subsequent
hemorrhage should be considered as a possible explanation of all of the above
findings.

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous MDCT axial images were obtained through the brain
without contrast material. Subsequently, helically acquired rapid axial
imaging was performed from the aortic arch through the brain during the
infusion of 70 mL of Omnipaque350 intravenous contrast material.
Three-dimensional angiographic volume rendered, curved reformatted and
segmented images were generated on a dedicated workstation. This report is
based on interpretation of all of these images.

   1) Sequenced Acquisition 18.0 s, 18.0 cm; CTDIvol = 50.2 mGy (Head) DLP =

1,230.9 mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Head) = 2,156 mGy-cm.

IMPRESSION:


1. Interval placement of a right frontal approach ventriculostomy catheter and
decompression of the ventricles.  The volume of acute blood products within
the medial nucleus of the left thalamus and within the ventricular system is
not appreciably changed.
2. No high-flow vascular malformation is identified.  Please note that a
vascular malformation could be compressed by the thalamic and intraventricular
hemorrhage and therefore occult on this exam.
3. Diffuse narrowing of the intracranial circulation, with some areas of at
least moderate focal narrowing, for example the proximal left M1 segment. 
This is likely secondary to a small to medium size vascular process, possibly
vasospasm secondary to subarachnoid hemorrhage and/or secondary to increased
intracranial pressure or a small to medium size vessel vasculopathy or
vasculitis.
4. Dental disease.  Recommend nonemergent dental consultation.

The physical exam on admission : Admission Physical Exam:
VS: T 98.3    HR 109    BP 153/80   RR 18    Sats 98% RA 
GEN: A&O, NAD

report:
EXAMINATION:  LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with recent cholecystectomy// eval biliary tree

TECHNIQUE:  Grey scale and color Doppler ultrasound images of the abdomen were
obtained.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION:


1. No biliary ductal dilatation.  Nonvisualization of reported biliary stent.
2. 8.2 x 2.3 x 2.5 cm subhepatic fluid collection with thickened rim within
the gallbladder fossa status post cholecystectomy.  Differential diagnosis
includes biloma, seroma, hematoma, gallbladder fossa abscess, or pancreatic
pseudocyst.  If indicated, MRCP with Eovist may be obtained for further
evaluation of fluid collection in relation to the biliary tree, and
specifically to look for bile leaks.
3. Possibly echogenic hepatic parenchyma could suggest hepatic steatosis which
can be better assessed on MRCP as recommended above.
EXAMINATION:  MRCP.

INDICATION:  Subhepatic fluid collection after cholecystectomy.  Query bile
leak.  Fever.

TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar T1- and T2- weighted images of the abdomen were
obtained on a 1.5 tesla magnet including sequences obtained prior to and
following intravenous administration of intravenous contrast.  10 cc of Eovist
was administered intravenously.

COMPARISON:  Ultrasound from earlier on the same day.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  Organized postoperative collection in the cholecystectomy bed. 
Differential diagnosis includes biloma although abscess cannot be excluded.

2.  Lack of visualized Eovist excretion suggesting hepatic dysfunction. 
Correlation with liver function tests and other clinical factors is
recommended.

3.  Mild fatty infiltration of the liver.

4.  Mild splenomegaly.
EXAMINATION:  CT-guided drainage of gallbladder fossa collection

INDICATION:  ___ with hx gallstone pancreatitis s/p ERCP plastic stent and lap
chole ___ now with biloma// Please evaluate for drainage of RUQ collection,
send for cultures and bilirrubin

COMPARISON:  MRCP from ___

PROCEDURE:  CT-guided drainage of gallbladder fossa collection.

OPERATORS:  Dr. ___, radiology fellow and Dr. ___,
attending radiologist. Dr. ___ personally supervised the trainee
during the key components of the procedure and reviewed and agrees with the
trainee's findings.

TECHNIQUE:  The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were
explained to the patient.  After a detailed discussion, informed written
consent was obtained.  A pre-procedure timeout using three patient identifiers
was performed per ___ protocol.

The patient was placed in a supine position on the CT scan table. Limited
preprocedure CT scan was performed to localize the collection.  Based on the
CT findings an appropriate skin entry site for the drain placement was chosen.
The site was marked.  Local anesthesia was administered with 1% Lidocaine
solution.

Using intermittent CT fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-G ___ needle was
inserted into the collection.  A sample of fluid was aspirated, confirming
needle position within the collection.  0.038 ___ wire was placed through
the needle and needle was removed. This was followed by placement of ___
Exodus pigtail catheter into the collection. The plastic stiffener and the
wire were removed.  The pigtail was deployed. The position of the pigtail was
confirmed within the collection via CT fluoroscopy.

Approximately 12 cc of serosanguineous fluid was aspirated with a sample sent
for microbiology evaluation and for total bilirubin. The catheter was secured
by a StatLock. The catheter was attached to suction bulb. Sterile dressing was
applied.

The procedure was tolerated well, and there were no immediate post-procedural
complications.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Spiral Acquisition 9.6 s, 29.5 cm; CTDIvol = 20.3 mGy (Body) DLP = 585.2
mGy-cm.
   2) Stationary Acquisition 1.1 s, 1.4 cm; CTDIvol = 11.3 mGy (Body) DLP =
16.3 mGy-cm.
   3) Stationary Acquisition 6.9 s, 1.4 cm; CTDIvol = 131.0 mGy (Body) DLP =
188.6 mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 803 mGy-cm.

SEDATION:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
1.5 mg Versed and 75 mcg fentanyl throughout the total intra-service time of
20 minutes during which patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously
monitored by an independent trained radiology nurse.

IMPRESSION: 

Successful CT-guided placement of an ___ pigtail catheter into the
gallbladder fossa collection. Samples were sent for microbiology evaluation
and for total bilirubin.

The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a past medical history of
hypertension and DM who presents with language difficulties and
right sided weakness.

Essentially, at her baseline she is quite independent, but gets
support from her daughter.  Yesterday, she took the ___ over to
her daughter apartment in the evening (around 1030pm).  Later
that evening, she was sitting in a recliner and fell asleep.  
Her
daughter woke her to move her to bed, but the patient was unable
to get up independently (unusual for her).  Her daughter had to
help her up and then help her to the bathroom.  She then went to
bed and went to sleep.  No obvious symptoms noted at this time.

This morning, at around 730 AM, Ms. ___ continued to complain
about how weak she was.  Her daughter noticed that her right arm
was hanging limply at her side.  Her speech was also abnormal,
slow and halting.  "it was like she knew what she was trying to
say, but the words weren't coming out clear".  No reported
paraphasias.  Comprehension was felt to be good.  Despite her
objections, Ms. ___ was brought to the ED by her daughter.

Of note, she has never had a similar episode before.

On neurologic review of systems, the patient denies headache,
lightheadedness, or confusion. Denies difficulty with producing
or comprehending speech. Denies loss of vision, blurred vision,
diplopia, vertigo, tinnitus, hearing difficulty, dysarthria, or
dysphagia. Denies focal muscle weakness, numbness, parasthesia.
Denies loss of sensation. Denies bowel or bladder incontinence 
or
retention. Denies difficulty with gait.  

On general review of systems, the patient denies fevers, rigors,
night sweats, or noticeable weight loss. Denies chest pain,
palpitations, dyspnea, or cough. Denies nausea, vomiting,
diarrhea, constipation, or abdominal pain. No recent change in
bowel or bladder habits. Denies dysuria or hematuria. Denies
myalgias, arthralgias, or rash.

At around 830 or 8 40 ___, he was sitting and eating dinner.  
Over
a period of perhaps ___ seconds, he had sudden onset of
numbness over his left face and left hand (remainder of arm was
not imvolved).  It was severe for perhaps 3 minutes and then
improved somewhat (but remained).  

This was followed by onset of left hand weakness and clumsiness. 

He notes dropping things several times with his left hand and
subsequently becoming concerned.  He called his physician to
explain the situation and felt that he had transient onset of
left tongue numbness.  He reports that his speech changed while
on the phone, but has trouble clarifying further.  There was no
aphasia, no word finding difficulty.

was called.

associated

significantly, his sensory hand is distinct from his 
presentation
today-  it tends to start in his hand and then over minutes

reports having 2 migraines for the 2 days prior to his
presentation.

or
tightness, palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea,

very complicated hospitalization from ___ during which

hospital course was c/b shock liver vs amiodarone toxicity with 
LFTs rising to 6000s, enterococcal UTI, MICU transfer for 
hypotension of unclear etiology. She was intubated due to 
respiratory failure likely ___ fluid overload, was diuresed,

The history of present illness : Mr. ___ is a pleasant ___ LT handed man w/
history of a-fib not on anti-coagulation, HTN, diet-controlled
DM, CAD s/p stents x2, psoriatic arthritis, and recent LT 
carotid
endarterectomy on ___, who presented w/ 3 days of
word-finding difficulty and right hand tremor, was found to have
left frontal subarachnoid hemorrhage which did not require
neurosurgical intervention and was thought to be due to
hyperperfusion syndrome. He was monitored on the stroke service
and had a routine EEG (results pending). The patient was
discharged home today on ___. 

Within fifteen minutes of returning home, the patient noticed
that he had onset of pins and needles in his right upper
extremity starting in his finger tips and progressing up into 
his
arm and shoulder within a matter of seconds. He also felt
tingling in his R leg. When he tried to lift the R arm it felt
heavy. He proceeded to call the neurology resident on-call who
urged him to call EMS and come to the ER. On arrival to the ER,
the tingling symptoms had resolved. 

The patient was discharged from the stroke service earlier 
today.
To recap, he had a planned L carotid endarterectomy on ___. On
___ he reported a few days of word finding difficulties and R
arm tremor. He presented to the ED and CT scan done revealed a L
frontal subarachnoid hemorrhage. CTA head and neck showed a L 
ICA
supraclinoid aneurysm which was not thought to be cause of the
SAH. Ultimately a cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome from the L 
CEA
is the leading theory for cause of SAH. The patient underwent
routine eeg (results pending) but was not started on seizure
medications as he did not have any events concerning for 
seizure.
He was maintained on aspirin/Plavix for the CEA and discharged
home today . Neuro exam was notable for R pronator drift and
minor word finding difficulty otherwise intact. 

Patient denies any confusion, whole body shaking, urinary
incontinence, tongue biting etc. 
 
On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred
vision, diplopia,  dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus
or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or
comprehending speech. No bowel or bladder incontinence or
retention. Denies difficulty with gait.
 
On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills.  No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies
cough, shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain or tightness,
palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation 
or
abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or bladder habits.  
No
dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

The history of present illness : Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male with h/o ___ disease with 
parkinsonian features, prostate cancer, who presented after 
unwitnessed fall at rehab.  Patient was found face down at his 
assisted living facility. It was his second fall that day.  He 
scraped his head.  It is unclear how long he was on the floor, 
but when he was found he was awake and alert.  He does not 
recall the fall.  Denies all other complaints.  As per his wife 
he has had frequent falls and syncopal episodes.  Patient uses 
walker to ambulate but often uses a wheelchair.  His daughter 
said that he is progressively declining and earlier this week he 
didn't recognize her and thought she was someone else.  

In the ED, initial vitals:  98.1 89 177/76 20 96%.  Patient 
underwent CT c-spine and CT head which showed no acute 
process/fracutres.  Labs were significant for creatinine of 3.7 
(baseline was 2.7 in ___.  EKG showed TWI and poor r-wave 
progression (which was old).  He received teatnus vaccine and 1 
L NS and was admitted for syncope work-up.  Vitals prior to 
transfer:  75 160/80 16 98%.
 
Currently, patinet has no complaints.  As per his wife and 
daughter, the congestion and noise he makes when breathing is 
new today and he did not have this yesterday.  They also think 
his speech is more difficult to understand
 
ROS: per HPI, denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, 
vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, 
shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, 
dysuria, hematuria.

CHEST, AP SEMISUPINE

The heart remains somewhat enlarged as on the prior chest x-ray.  Opacities
are now noted in the left lower lobe and a rounded density in the right lower
lobe is seen peripherally.  This was not present on the prior two chest x-rays
and is likely therefore some acute process rather than a mass.

The pulmonary vasculature is somewhat more prominent and I suspect the
presence of new onset of failure.

IMPRESSION:  Increased lung densities particular in the lower lobes likely due
to failure.

The patient reports his last drink was ___ at 4am.  He reports

continues to drink. He denies any acute stressors.

The history of present illness : ___ F PMHx CAD s/p DES to RCA ___, restented ___, diastolic 
heart failure (EF>75% ___, DM2, ESRD s/p cadaveric 
transplant c/b CKD w recent hospital stay (___) for 
decompensated diastolic heart failure, discharged home, now 
returning with 1 day of intermittent dizziness. Initial 
hospitalization notable for presentation w acute onset of SOB in 
setting of medication dosing confusion (was not taking 
lasix/metolazone as prescribed). She was diuresed to 152 lbs 
(dry-weight 145lbs, but had creatinine increase to 3), placed on 
home lasix 80mg daily and discharged home. At time of discharge, 
still had crackles on exam that were attributed to interstitial 
lung disease (had increasing BUN/Cr as well, so felt to be 
clinically dry). Since discharge, patient reports compliance 
with medication (had been instructed to hold lasix and 
metolazone x 1 day). On the afternoon of the day of admission, 
patient's daughter noted her to be diaphoretic and confused. The 
patient reported feeling "light-headed" at that time, which was 
nonpositional, nonexertional. Denied any associated fevers, CP, 
dyspnea, edema, syncope, PND or edema. Per daughter, ___ at that 
time was ___. Reported chronic cough stable, nonproductive. She 
was brought to ___ ED for further evaluation.  
.  
In ED, initial vital signs were 97 54 136/32 16 98%RA. Exam was 
significant for finger stick 73, crackles across lung fields, 
negative orthostatics. Labs were notable for WBC 6.1 (last 5.2), 
Hct 34.1 (last 33.8), Cr 2.8 (last 3.0, baseline 2.0), BNP 4033 
(upper-end of baseline); trop<.01. EKG was unchanged from 
baseline. CXR w e/o pulmonary edema, R-sided opacity most likely 
vascular prominence but unable to rule-out infectious 
consolidation. Patient initially felt by ED to be volume down, 
given 250cc NS, but she subsequently desatting to 92% on RA. 
Patient was evaluated by cardiology attending who felt that 
patient likely remained in mild diastolic failure, recommended 
observation overnight, repeat TTE in AM, restart lasix in AM, 
rule-out pressence of infectious process. Vitals on transfer 
were 97.4 57 110/40 18 94%RA. Access was 20g LEJx1.  
.  
On arrival to the floor, patient comfortable, not short of 
breath, vital signs 97.5 146/45, 59 18 94%RA 153lbs. Confirmed 
above story but felt that ___ checked at home was 48 (had been 
reported as 78 by ED). On review of systems she denied of chest 
pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, 
orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope.

report:
EXAMINATION:  Chest (PA and lateral)

INDICATION:  ___ man presenting with dyspnea,  cough, fatigue for 1
week ; evaluate for acute process.

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Portable chest radiograph exams dated ___ and ___.

1.  Cardiomegaly without acute intrathoracic process.
2.  New 5-mm left lung nodule, amenable to further evaluation with a
non-emergent chest CT. At this time, the right lung opacity versus old rib
fracture can also be assessed.
EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with CAD, HFrEF, URI, ___ here with volume
overload, now with new WBC of 17  // evidence of new infiltrate     evidence
of new infiltrate

COMPARISON:  Comparison to ___ at 16:13

IMPRESSION: 

Status post median sternotomy with stably enlarged cardiac contour which may
reflect cardiomegaly or pericardial effusion. Clinical correlation is advised.
Lung volumes are slightly lower with streaky opacities at both lung bases
likely reflecting atelectasis. Minimal peribronchial cuffing suggests an
element of mild interstitial edema. No pleural effusions. No evidence of
pneumothorax.

INDICATION:  **Please perform with doppler**r/o evidence of obstruction o

was performed.

IMPRESSION:

waveforms which can be related to right heart failure or tricuspid
regurgitation.
2. No focal liver lesions, but nodular appearing liver; cirrhosis cannot be
ruled out on the basis of this exam. Congestive hepatopathy could be
considered given finding #1.
3. Mild intra-abdominal ascites.

The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman with HCV on Harvoni, HTN and T2DM, 
who presents from clinic with hyponatremia and ___. 

 

The patient shares she was in her usual state of health until 
about 9 days ago, when she began to experience lightheadedness 
and weakness. She has also had a headache for about 4 days. She 
doesn't recall how the symptoms started but she states that her 
symptoms have been improving since yesterday. 

 

She presented to liver clinic for regularly scheduled follow up, 
and was found to have a Na of 116 and Cr of 1.8 (baseline 1), 
and then sent to the ED. 

 

In ED initial VS: 96.6  89 160/83 18 100% RA. Exam was notable 
for normal neuro exam. Labs notable for Na 117, Cl 74, Cr 1.6, 
Bicarb 19, Glucose 119, WBC 10.6, Hb 10.9 (stable), UA with 11 
WBC and many bacteria and epis. Repeat Na was 120. CXR showed - 
. EKG showed Qtc 594. 

 

On arrival to the MICU, the patient gives the above history. Of 
note, she mentions that she was started on HCZT two to three 
months ago, but denies any other recent medication changes. She 
has had no fevers, chills, chest pain, dysuria, N/V, diarrhea, 
dark or bloody stools.

and has had prior admissions for aspiration pneumonia which has

antibiotics. He also had a chest CT concerning for abscess

On admission, his vitals were: T 98.4 BP 133/50 HR 40 RR19 and

assessment, and recommendations.

The history of present illness : Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of HTN, HLD, 
OSA on CPAP, and depression presenting with visual 
hallucinations after coming back from a cruise to ___ and 
___. 

She states that on ___ she noticed irritability and 
increased tension between her and her friends on her vacation. 
She believes she started seeing and hearing people who were not 
there later that day. She was unaware that she was hallucinating 
at this time. 

When she arrived back home on ___ her daughter noted 
that she seemed disheveled and confused. A few nights later, the 
patient called the daughter because she saw 10 "refugees" in her 
house and didn't know why they were there. Her daughter came to 
the house and saw that there were no other people in the house. 
At this time the patient realized that she had been 
hallucinating and presented to the ED. 

patient's daughter ___ says that she was a skilled enthusiast 
at crossword puzzles, but with mild cognitive decline for the 
past year (word-finding difficulties, and mixing up family 
members).

The patient denies any focal neurologic deficits, changes in 
sensation, gait problems, falls, other vision changes, 
headaches, dizziness, fevers, chills, or night sweats. 

She was drinking 2.5 glasses of wine per day on vacation and 
denies marijuana use of any kind, tobacco use, or any other drug 
use. 

She has never had problems like this before.

In the ED:
- Initial vital signs: AF HR 73 BP 165/56 RR 18 O2 98% RA
- Exam notable for: confusion, disorientation with tangential 
speech, inattention and paraphasic errors, but otherwise mental 
status is intact (Calculation intact, can do DOWB, can follow

intracranial abnormality

acetaminophen 1,000 mg PO.
- Consults:
1. Psychiatry: recommend medical work up for VH, neurology 
consult
2. Neurology: recommend MRI brain with contrast

Vitals on transfer: AF HR 60 BP 162/71 RR 18 O2 95% RA

Upon arrival to the floor, she notes the above history and 
continues to remain medically stable. She did not endorse active 
hallucinations during our interview.

affirms vision changes (hallucinations), affirms polyuria ___
