report:
HISTORY:  Intubation at outside hospital for head bleed.

TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP view of the chest.

COMPARISON:  ___ at 9:25.

IMPRESSION:

1. Standard positioning of endotracheal and enteric tubes.

2. Bibasilar opacities, more pronounced on the left, which could reflect areas
of atelectasis though infection or aspiration are additional possibilities.  A
small left pleural effusion may be present.

EXAMINATION:  CTA HEAD WANDW/O C AND RECONS AND CTA NECK W/ RECONS

INDICATION:  History: ___ with known L parietal and occiptal IPH // eval for
interval change in IPH, eval for ?underlying vascular abnormalities

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain without
contrast material. Subsequently, rapid axial imaging was performed from the
aortic arch through the brain during infusion of Omnipaque intravenous
contrast material. Images were processed on a separate workstation with
display of curved reformats, 3D volume redendered images, and maximum
intensity projection images.

DOSE:  DLP: 2308 mGy-cm

COMPARISON:  Outside head CT performed at ___ earlier
the same day at 08:32 (4 hours earlier).

IMPRESSION: 

Large multicompartmental parenchymal hemorrhage involving the left occipital,
parietal and temporal lobes with perihemorrhagic edema, but no evidence of
underlying arterial infarct.The lobar pattern, subarachnoid and subdural
extension of hemorrhage, and presence of blood-fluid level at time of
presentation, in an elderly patient, all favor a diagnosis of underlying
cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). Associated mass effect with 8mm rightward
shift of normally-midline structures. No evidence of active extravasation
("spot sign"), arteriovenous malformation, or cerebral venous thrombosis on
accompanying CTA.  Left superior cerebellar artery, very poorly-demonstrated.
Panlobular emphysema.

The history of present illness : ___ with history of 4V CABG almost ___ years ago, DMII, HTN, HLD, 
and MS admitted with chest pain that awoke her from sleep this 
morning at 2a characterized by substernal pressure radiating to 
both arms associated with mild diaphoresis but without dyspnea, 
loss of conciousness, jaw pain, palpitations, anxiety or other 
symptoms. Her pain was partially relieved after taking 5 SL 
nitroglycerin tablets. She developed similar symptoms this 
morning while driving to take her daughter to an appointment at 
___, and was referred to the ___ by her daughter (who is an 
___). She reports she has never had pain like this before. She 
rarely takes NTG. She reports undergoing catheterization 
approximately ___ years ago leading to CABG the next day, though 
she can not recall the circumstances surrounding those events.

At baseline, she is able to ambulate only short distances before 
getting fatigued and developing parasthesias in her legs (which 
she attributes to her multiple sclerosis). She is unable to walk 
around a supermarket without stopping to rest. She denies ever 
experiencing peripheral edema, orthopnea, or paroxysmal 
nocturnal dyspnea symptoms.

In the ___, initial vitals were 98.1, 78, 177/81, 20, 96%. EKG 
was notable for sinus rhythm, normal axis, normal intervals, ST 
dep in II, aVF, V3-6 (no prior for comparison). Initial 
troponins were negative, other labs notable for BG 371, anion 
gap 7. She was given  aspirin 325mg x1 shortly after arrival, 
metoprolol 5mg IV x1 for hypertension, NTG SL 0.4mg x1 for chest 
pain, and a hep gtt was started. She had a CXR that did not show 
any acute processes. Patient's daughter reported to ___ staff 
that patient had a positive stress test several weeks ago. 
Cardiology was consulted in the ___ and recommended admission for 
unstable angina. Of note, during safety questions pt states 
depression and feelings of hurting self but no plan so she had 
sitter at bedside.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
(+) Per HPI. Also endorses significant fatigue in past several 
months ("I can sleep all day."), poor appetite leading to 52lb 
weight loss over past ___ years, hair loss over many years, 
chronic non-productive cough worsened with increased cigarette 
consumption, chronic parasthesias in her legs, chronic 
lightheadedness/dizziness, and poor vision. The day prior to 
these events (___), she developed hypoglycemia to ___ while 
driving; did not take extra insulin or miss ___ meal.
(-) Cardiac: Denies palpitations, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, 
orthopnea, peripheral edema/swelling, syncope or presyncope.
(-) General: Denies subjective fevers at home, chills, rigors, 
night sweats, headache, diplopia, odynophagia, dysphagia, 
lymphadenopathy, prior history of stroke or TIA, cyanosis, 
cough, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, nausea, vomiting, 
diarrhea, melena, hematochezia, hematemesis, known pulmonary 
embolism or DVT, myalgias, joint pains, new brusing, new 
bleeding, dysuria, exertional buttock or calf pain.

encephalopathy. During that time, patient had been altered in

one word at a time. Neurology was consulted in the ED and had 
recommended CT imaging, and then had a witnessed seizure in the 
CT scanner with rhythmic shaking. Patient then received IV 1 mg 
Ativan and was loaded with Keppra 1500 mg and was then found to 
be flu positive. Patient was admitted to the medical floor, and 
his seizure was thought to be provoked in the setting of being 
flu positive.  His anti-epileptics were changed to Keppra 1 gram 
in AM and ___, and on HD days, additional 500 mg Keppra, and to 
continue carbamazepine 300 mg immediately following HD. During 
admission, CT had also demonstrated some periodontal disease, 
and the patient was set up to have formal dental evaluation. 

Patient was then seen today at HD and was found to again be 
altered with fever. Given this, he did not undergo dialysis. He 
was also found to be hypotensive to the ___ on admission to the 
ED. Patient at HD was found to have 1 word sentences, not 
carrying on sentences, and required multiple repetitive 
questions before answering questions. 
 
In the ED, initial vitals: 101.5 ___ 20 90% RA
- Exam notable for: known right facial droop.

right lower lobe pneumonia.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is a ___ old right-handed woman with a past 
medical
history of HTN not on medication, hyperlipidemia, 
hypothyroidism,
legal blindness in left eye who presents with acute onset right
sided numbness, weakness and speech difficulties. 

Patient was in her usual state of health on awakening this
morning at 5:30am. She feel back asleep until 8:30am. She felt
"funny" but has trouble describing what she means, possibly just
fatigue. Around 9am, she had acute onset numbness and tingling 
in
the right thumb and pointer finger that crept up her arm, to
include her face and then she noticed it in her leg. She is
unclear how long it took the symptoms to become maximal, but she
feels it is possibly up to a half hour. She went to the bathroom
to brush her teeth and had difficulty manipulating the tooth
brush with her right hand. The right side of her mouth was also
numb and felt weird while brushing. She walked to her bedroom to
get dressed for the day, and felt that her walking was off, and
thought she might be weak in her right leg. She tried putting on
her bra and buttoning her shirt but her hand wasn't working
properly. She called her husband who thought her speech was
"off." He is not available for history, but patient says her
speech may have been slow. She did not have trouble speaking or
forming words, or trouble understanding her husband. She is not
sure if there was slurred speech. Her husband urged her to go to
the ED, but she declined. 

The symptoms persisted into the afternoon and when her husband
returned, he took her to the ED at ___ where her exam was
notable for a facial droop and prominent weakness in the right
leg. She also had decreased sensation throughout the right leg
right upper
arm and right face. She underwent CT head which was negative for
bleed. Given that she presented 5 hours after LKW, tPA was not
given. She also had basic lab work and was given aspirin 325mg x
1. She reported that her symptoms improved. She was transferred
to ___ for further management. 

Currently she is complaining of persistent sensory deficits on
the right side as well as right hand clumsiness. 

On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred
vision, diplopia, dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus
or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties comprehending speech.
No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. 

On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills.  No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies
cough, shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain or tightness,
palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation 
or
abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or bladder habits.  
No
dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

to thrive.

Patient had recent fall about four weeks ago when she was in her 
bathroom and had a mechanical fall in which she fell forward and 
hit hear nose resulting in a brief nosebleed. She spends most of 
the day in bed and is very fatigued. She has no appetite, food 
tastes "like dirt" and has decreased thirst. She has primarily 
eating cream of wheat. She notes significant weight loss, about 
60 pounds over the past 6 months. Also notes up to four episodes 
of green stool daily with occasional incontinence. Her sister is 
concerned she may have had more frequent falls as the patient 
has multiple bruises. Of note, she lives with her ___ 
mother who is unable to care for the patient at home. She was 
seen in clinic this morning with plan for direct admission for 
failure to thrive and starting tube feeds but was sent to the ED 
as no beds were available.

Of note, patient was in clinic on ___ for her C5D15 FOLFOX. 
At that time plan for was a four week treatment break. She has 
recently started on pancreatic enzyme supplementation in 
addition to dronabinol and remeron. She had been using marijuana 
lollipops and believes this helped with her appetite but she ran 
out.

On arrival to the ED, initial vitals were 97.8 85 85/52 16 99%

membranes. Labs were notable for WBC 3.0, H/H 11.9/32.0, Plt 
204, Na 130, K 3.2, BUN/Cr ___, Mg 1.5, LFTs wnl, lactate 1.2.

odynophagia. Reports all food tastes like dirt. No N/V. Reports 
up to 4 loose stools per day with occaisional incontinence. No 
dysuria. Uses cane at baseline. No new rashes or joint pains.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with locally advanced pancreatic cancer and
failure to thrive. 20kg weight loss so need for >3mo TFs.  // Please place G-J
tube for feeding

COMPARISON:  ___ tube placement from ___.

TECHNIQUE:  OPERATORS: Dr. ___ resident and Dr. ___,
___ radiologist performed the procedure. Dr. ___
supervised the trainee during the key components of the procedure and has
reviewed and agrees with the trainee's findings.
ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administrating divided doses of
100 mcg of fentanyl and 2 mg of midazolam throughout the total intra-service
time of 46 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were
continuously monitored by an independent trained radiology nurse. 1% lidocaine
was injected in the skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the access site.
MEDICATIONS:  Fentanyl, Versed, 1% lidocaine.
CONTRAST: 15 ml of Optiray contrast.
FLUOROSCOPY TIME AND DOSE:  1.4 min, 205 mGy

PROCEDURE:  1. Placement of a MIC gastrojejunostomy tube.

PROCEDURE DETAILS: Following the discussion of the risks, benefits and
alternatives to the procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the
patient. The patient was then brought to the angiography suite and placed
supine on the exam table.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed per ___
protocol. The tube site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.

A scout image of the abdomen was obtained. The stomach was insufflated through
the indwelling nasogastric tube. Using a marker, the skin was marked using
palpation to feel the costal margins and the liver edge was marked using
ultrasound. Ultrasound images were stored.

Under fluoroscopic guidance, 3 T fastener buttons were sequentially deployed
in a triangular position elevating the stomach to the anterior abdominal wall.
Intra-gastric position was confirmed with aspiration of air and injection of
contrast. A 19 gauge needle was introduced under fluoroscopic guidance and
position confirmed using an injection of dilute contrast. The needle
trajectory was directed towards the pylorus. A Amplatz wire was introduced and
coiled within the stomach. A small skin incision was made along the needle,
and the needle was removed.

A 6 ___ sheath was placed. A Kumpe catheter was then introduced over the
wire and the Amplatz wire was exchanged for ___ wire. The wire and a
Kumpe cathter was used to advance the wire into the ___ part of the duodenum. 
The wire was removed, and contrast was hand injected to confirm positioning in
a post pyloric position.  The sheath was then removed, and the gastrostomy
tract was serially dilated.  A peel-away sheath was placed over the wire. A 16
___ MIC gastrojejunostomy catheter was advanced over the wire into
position. The sheath was then peeled away.

The wire and sheath were removed. The catheter was locked by instilling 9 ml
of dilute contrast into the balloon in the distal stomach and then pulled back
after confirming the position of the catheter with a contrast injection. The
catheter was then flushed, capped and secured to the skin. Sterile dressings
were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no
immediate complications.

IMPRESSION: 

Successful placement of a 16 ___ MIC gastrojejunostomy tube with its tip in
the proximal jejunum. The gastric port should not be used for 24 hours.
INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with severe persistent diarrhea for months
following chemotherapy - prior CTs show diffuse colitis that was never clearly
explained and off chemo for a while now so shouldn't be still ongoing  // eval
for presence/progression/worsening of previously seen colitis

TECHNIQUE:  Single phase split bolus contrast: MDCT axial images were acquired
through the abdomen and pelvis following intravenous contrast administration
with split bolus technique.
Oral contrast was administered.
Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed and reviewed on PACS.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Sequenced Acquisition 0.5 s, 0.2 cm; CTDIvol = 9.3 mGy (Body) DLP = 1.9
mGy-cm.
   2) Stationary Acquisition 12.0 s, 0.2 cm; CTDIvol = 204.7 mGy (Body) DLP =
40.9 mGy-cm.
   3) Spiral Acquisition 8.5 s, 54.9 cm; CTDIvol = 7.7 mGy (Body) DLP = 415.2
mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 458 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  CTA ___

IMPRESSION:


1. Improvement of wall thickening involving the descending and sigmoid colon. 
There is persistent wall thickening in the transverse colon and right ___,
___ be reactive, from venous congestion, or represent colitis.
2. Stable appearance of the patient's known pancreatic mass with surrounding
upper abdominal lymphadenopathy.
3. Small volume of free peritoneal air, may be related to percutaneous
gastrostomy, clinically correlate.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : ___ female with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, 
anxiety, and depression presents from outside hospital with two 
weeks of shortness of breath and elevated troponin, D-dimer, and 
BNP with CXR with vascular congestion, bilateral interstitial 
edema, and right sided pleural effusion. 

Reports acute onset of SOB, DOE about two weeks prior to 
admission. Presented to ___ at that time and received Ativan for 
anxiety. Noted no improvement in respiratory symptoms. Family 
friend brought patient to ___ on day of admission who referred 
patient to ___ for CXR and EKG. In ___, VS 98.2, 92, 13, 
99%. Troponin 0.21, BNP 9244, D-dimer 683. EKG without ischemic 
changes. CXR with right pleural effusion, cardiomegaly, vascular 
congestion and interstitial edema bilaterally. Patient started 
on CPAP for worsened exam, heparin gtt, asa 325 and transferred 
to ___ for evaluation. 

At ___ ___, initial VS: 97.8, 58, 138/70, 18, 95% NC 
Labs notable for: 
-CBC 13.1, hgb 12.8, plt 219. Na 129, Cr 0.8.
-BNP 8151. Troponin 0.16. 
-VBG 7.42/34/51
-Lactate 1.8
-UA no bacteria, mod leuk, net nitr, tr prot.  
-Heparin gtt was continued 
-Underwent urgent CTA to evaluate for PE that showed bilateral 
segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli. There is no 
evidence
of right heart strain. Assessment for pulmonary infarction is 
limited due to the patient's underlying lung disease. Large 
right and small left pleural effusion. Mediastinal 
lymphadenopathy, clinical correlation is recommended. Moderate 
atherosclerotic disease.
-Cardiology consulted who recommended continuation of heparin 
gtt, lasix 
- Patient received Lasix 10mg IV x1 and was admitted to CCU for 
close monitoring. 

Vitals on transfer: 97.9, 63, 140/61, 26, 93%NC 

On the floor, patient denied chest pain, dyspnea. 
Endorsed above details. Denies pedal edema, orthopnea, PND, 
abdominal distension. DOE worsening and now feels like she was 
immobile for at least the last few days. No recent air travel or 
long car rides. Mother and brother with history of clot, but 
unsure of circumstances and if any hypercoagulability workup was 
performed. Has not seen PCP regularly, not up to date on 
colonoscopy/mammogram. 

Slight decreased po intake in last two weeks, nausea and emesis 
once today, but none currently. Diarrhea for last few days, no 
melena or hematochezia. No fevers, chills, new numbness or 
tingling, dysuria, abdominal pain.

========================
Tele:  NSR
GEN:  Pleasant female, NAD. SOB with speaking full sentences
HEENT:  PERRL. Sclera anicteric. MMM. 
NECK:  JVP to mid neck. 
CV:  RRR, no murmurs rubs or gallops 
LUNGS:  Decreased breath sounds at bilateral lung bases, R>L. no 
crackles or wheeze. Belly breathing. 
ABD:  +BS, soft, mildly distended, no TTP 
EXT:  1+ pedal edema. Warm and well perfused. 
NEURO:  CN2-12 intact, ___ strength UE and ___ bilaterally
report:
EXAMINATION:  CTA chest pain.

INDICATION:  History: ___ with shortness of breath and elevated D-dimer

TECHNIQUE:  Axial multidetector CT images were obtained through the thorax
after the uneventful administration of intravenous contrast.
Reformatted coronal, sagittal, thin slice axial images, and oblique maximal
intensity projection images were submitted to PACS and reviewed.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Stationary Acquisition 0.5 s, 0.5 cm; CTDIvol = 1.5 mGy (Body) DLP = 0.8
mGy-cm.
   2) Stationary Acquisition 4.5 s, 0.5 cm; CTDIvol = 13.7 mGy (Body) DLP =
6.8 mGy-cm.
   3) Spiral Acquisition 4.0 s, 31.4 cm; CTDIvol = 14.6 mGy (Body) DLP = 459.4
mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 467 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  None

IMPRESSION:



1. Bilateral pulmonary emboli involving both upper lobes and left lower lobe.
2. Large right and moderate to large left pleural effusions with bilateral
lower lobe and right middle lobe atelectasis.
3. Moderate cardiomegaly with biatrial and left ventricular enlargement. 
Reflux of contrast in the hepatic veins and IVC suggests an element of right
heart failure.
4. Collapse of the trachea and mainstem bronchi cell suggestive of
tracheobronchomalacia.
5. Diffuse airway wall thickening suggests chronic airways disease.
6. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy is likely reactive.

NOTIFICATION:  The findings were discussed by Dr. ___ with Dr. ___ on
___ at 8:32 ___, 5 minutes after discovery of the findings.

The history of present illness : ___ with PMH significant for ___ disease with recent 
admission for L2-4 discectomy and fusion, discharged to rehab on 
___, who presented from rehab today for productive cough over 
the past few days. The patient also reports general malaise and 
weakness. Family believes he may have been overmedicated with MS 
contin this past weekend. He also complained of continued pain 
post-operatively as well as in his right shoulder. Has had a 
foley catheter in place since last admission. He has not been 
getting full ___ because he has been lethargic. He has also been 
complaining of some difficulty swallowing food, daughter unclear 
if that has been from poor mental status.  
Of note, the patient was recently admitted to ___ from 
___ with worsening back pain. He underwent L2-L4 
discectomy and fusion. Hospital course was noncomplicated and he 
was discharged to rehab on ___.  
In the ED, initial vitals were: 97.9 65 107/56 18 97% RA.  
Exam notable for crackles in the right lung base. Labs notable 
for WBC 4.6, H/H 10.2/33.0, Cr 1.2, lactate 1.1, normal LFTs. CT 
ABD/pelvis showed s/p L2-3 and L3-L4 discectomy and placement of 
anterior spacers with multiple foci of intra-abdominal and 
retroperitoneal free air c/w post-operative status, 
pneumomediastimum and trace right pneumothorax, also likely 
related to post-op status, and RLL pneumonia. RLL pneumonia was 
confirmed on CXR. L-spine and Rt shoulder XR were negative for 
fracture.  
The patient was given 1L LR, vanc/cefepime, and continued on 
home medications.  
Vitals prior to transfer were: 97.9 86 132/76 16 100% RA.  
On the floor, 97.8, 123/71, 62, 18, 99RA. Daughter notes that 
patient is doing better with his mental status since getting 
antibiotics. Patient is able to recount some of history. Denies 
recent fevers, but daughter is not sure if this is true.  
 
Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or 
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or 
congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain 
or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or 
bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : ___ w/PMHx of ESRD on PD, HTN, and anemia, who presents with 
dyspnea and orthostasis. Patient presented to peritoneal 
dialysis today and reported to the nurse that he had been 
experiencing several days of dyspnea with minimal exertion, 
dizziness upon standing, and mild cough. Denied any fevers. O2 
sat 92%. PD nurse found diminished breaths sounds on left; SBP 
was checked and decreased from 130 seated to 110 standing (with 
the pt complaining of dizziness). Patient was referred to the ED 
for further evaluation.

Of note, patient was recently admitted to ___ from ___ 
for cough and shortness of breath that was thought to be due to 
a viral URI, in addition to mild fluid overload in the setting 
of less fluid drainage from peritoneal dialysis during the 2 
weeks prior to admission. He had a CXR on ___ that showed left 
lower opacity questionable for pneumonia, as well as new mild 
cardiomegaly compared to his CXR from 1 week prior, and small 
bilateral pulmonary effusions. During the admission he received 
a one-time dose of levofloxacin in ED and a single dose of 
azithromycin 500mg PO on day 1 of admission. Given his clinical 
picture, there was low suspicion for bacterial pneumonia as a 
cause for his symptoms, so antibiotics were discontinued. An 
echocardiogram was not performed at that time.

On arrival to the ED, initial vitals were 97.8, 104, BP 169/78, 
RR 18, 95% RA. Labs were notable for BNP 6483, Hgb 8.9 (recent 
baseline Hgb 9.0), and lactate 1.6. At 13:25, he was noted to 
have SpO2 88% on RA and was placed on 3L NC. Patient reported 
that he can normally walk up to 200 ft, but has not been able to 
over the past few days. He denied orthopnea, PND or chest pain. 
He endorsed a few episodes of dizzness with ambulation last 
week, but none this week. In the ED, a CXR showed increased 
right pleural effusion (now moderate) with overlying atelectasis 
(underlying consolidation cannot be excluded) and trace left 
pleural effusion that is slightly decreased. Patient received 
Lasix 40mg IV at 1530.

Vitals prior to transfer were 73 117/60 16 100% 3L NC. On 
arrival to the floor, Pt's VS:
98.1, 90, 18, 100% RA.

Pt was alert and comfortable. States that he had been drinking 
more fluids over the last ___ days ("70% more than normal") 
because he had been feeling dizzy when standing and thought that 
he was dehydrated. He also has been taking more off during his 
PD, usually 800mL but now 1L for the last ___ days. He has had 
dyspnea on exertion for a few weeks. No orthopnea or pain aside 
from R ankle, no cough, fever, nausea vomiting, or diarrhea. Pt 
still makes small amounts of urine.

ROS: (+) Per HPI, dyspnea on exertion, ankle swelling
(-) Denies fever, changes in appetite, chest pain, abdominal 
pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, 
hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : ___ yo male with signficant PMH for CAD (s/p multiple PCI), HTN 
and stage 5 CKD who presents w/ worsening angina w/ new pressure 
symptoms. The patient's cardiolgist is Dr ___ has been 
contemplating getting a cath given worsening angina and recently 
started on imdur recently. Patient reports he woke up at 730 
this morning with chest pain radiating towards the left and 
right sides with mild pressure like symptoms while at rest. 
Patient was concerned about having increasing symptoms now at 
rest and notes this was different from the increasing anginal 
symptoms over the past 3 months. Patient took 2 SL nitroglycern 
at home without resolution of chest pain. En route to the ED he 
recieved a third SL nitro which relieved his chest pain. Patient 
is requesting Nephrology involvement prior to catheterization 
given recent discussion of potential for cath with his 
nephrologist. Cardiac surgery was consulted for further 
evaluation of surgical intervention.

VS- T 97.9 BP 149/72 HR 74 RR 18 POx 100% RA
Weight 112.1kg 
GENERAL: Obese male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. exotropia noted 
on right side 
NECK: Supple with flat JVP cm  
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2. +III/VI systolic murmur heard 
throughout the precordium and radiates to carotids. No thrills, 
lifts. No S3 or S4.  
LUNGS: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no 
crackles, wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. +reducible 
umbilical hernia.  
EXTREMITIES: no cyanosis/clubbing or edema.
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. 
Oncholysis is noted bilaterally on hands and feet consistent 
with onchomycosis 
PULSES: Right: DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: DP 2+ ___ 2+
report:
CHEST RADIOGRAPH

INDICATION:  Evaluation for acute process.

COMPARISON:  ___.

FINDINGS:  As compared to the previous radiograph, there is no relevant
change.  Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette without evidence of overt
pulmonary edema.  No pleural effusions.  No pneumothorax.  No pneumonia. 
Normal hilar and mediastinal contours.
SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST

REASON FOR EXAM:  Status post cardiac surgery.

Comparison is made with preop radiograph from ___.

Mild cardiomegaly has minimally increased.  There is postoperative mediastinal
widening.  Swan-Ganz catheter tip is in the main pulmonary artery.  There is
mild vascular congestion.  There are multifocal atelectases in the left mid
and left lower lobe lungs.  There is a small left effusion.  There is no
evident pneumothorax.  ET tube is seen in standard position.  NG tube tip is
out of view below the diaphragm.  Mediastinal and chest tubes are in place. 
Sternal wires are aligned.  There is an AVR.
SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST

REASON FOR EXAM:  Status post AVR and CABG, assess for pleural effusions.

Large left pleural effusion has increased.  ET tube is in standard position. 
Swan-Ganz catheter tip is in the main pulmonary artery.  Mediastinal and left
chest tubes remain in place.  Small right pleural effusion is unchanged.  Mild
vascular congestion is stable.  Multifocal atelectases in the left lung have
increased in the lower lobe.  Cardiomegaly and widened mediastinum are stable.
SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST

REASON FOR EXAM:  Status post CABG.

Comparison is made with prior study ___.

There has been markedly improving aeration of the left lung.  Small left
effusion has improved.  Rounded opacity in the left mid lung could be fluid in
the fissure and/or atelectasis.  Widened mediastinum has improved.  Right
lower lobe opacities have increased, consistent with increasing atelectasis. 
Small right effusion is unchanged.  Lines and tubes are in unchanged standard
position.  Mild vascular congestion is stable.
REASON FOR EXAMINATION:  Evaluation of the patient after CABG for assessment
of pneumothorax.

COMPARISON:  ___.

Heart size and mediastinum are stable.  Post-sternotomy wires are
unremarkable.  There is no evidence of pneumothorax.  Bibasilar atelectasis
and bilateral pleural effusions are noted.  Subcutaneous air is new in the
left upper chest wall, but no clear pneumothorax is seen, attention to this
area on the subsequent studies is required.  Note is made of the lucency along
the left mediastinal border that might reflect pneumothorax.
INDICATION:  CABG and AVR.

COMPARISON:  Multiple chest x-rays from ___ to ___.

FINDINGS:

The patient had a sternotomy for AVR and CABG.  Left lower lobe atelectasis
and small pleural effusion have slightly improved.  Right minimal atelectasis
and effusion have also improved.  Residual subcutaneous air is seen in the
left lower neck.  There is no pneumothorax.  Mediastinal and cardiac contours
are mildly enlarged and unchanged.  Coronary artery stents are seen on the
lateral view.

CONCLUSION:

Improvement of expected findings after recent cardiac surgery with bilateral
atelectasis, pleural effusion, more prominent on the left Side.
NON-INVASIVE DUPLEX VENOUS ULTRASOUND OF THE LEFT LOWER EXTREMITY

CLINICAL INDICATION:  Swollen leg in a ___ man status post cardiac
surgery.

Pulse Doppler waveforms are symmetric and normal in the right and left common
femoral veins.

In the left lower extremity, all of the veins from the common femoral to the
popliteal fossa are fully and easily compressible.  The posterior tibial and
peroneal veins are visualized and also fully compressible.  Color flow and
pulse Doppler augmentation is normal throughout.

CONCLUSION:  No evidence of DVT in the left lower extremity.
HISTORY:  PICC line placement.

COMPARISON:  ___.

IMPRESSION:

1. Right PICC tip ends in the lower SVC.  No pneumothorax.

2. Worsening left lower lobe atelectasis.

Telephone notification of ___, PICC line nurse, ___ at noon on
___.

input_dict.hpi_text:
The history of present illness : Ms. ___ is a ___ F s/p DCD liver transplant ___ w/mild
acute cellular rejection p/w medication non-compliance and
elevated LFTs. She was recently admitted to the transplant
surgery service for elevated LFTs, found to have mild acute
cellular rejection on biopsy. She had her cyclosporin goal
increased to 200-250, and dose increased to 200 bid upon
discharge ___. She underwent ERCP yesterday ___, during which
the old plastic CBD stent was removed, and two new stents were
placed, one in the left hepatic duct and the other in the right
hepatic duct. The 10mm known anastomotic stricture was 
evaluated,
with diameter found to be improved since last ERCP ___. A 
few
small stones and sludge were removed and the stricture was then
dilated using a balloon. The dobhoff was also d/ced per 
patient's
request as she reported taking better PO. LFTs on ___ were
elevated from discharge on ___. ALT 152 (107), AST 107 (69), AP
442 (297), Tbili 0.5. cyclo level was 143. The clinical called
her to increase her cyclo dose to 250bid, but she refused to 
take
the increased dose, and was instructed to come to the ED. Here
she endorses taking all of her medications except for the
cyclosporin, which she did not want to take at a higher level 
due
to nausea/vomiting and abd pain after taking the cyclosporin, 
and
her frustrations with her husband whose instructions she did not
want to follow. She endorsed feeling very upset and frustrated
recently, without SI or HI. She continues to have some diarrhea
___ / day) and pruritis, but is otherwise doing well, w/o abd
pain, tolerating more PO, at 2 meals a day with snacks in
between. Per the clinic, she is not taking some of her other
immunosuppression medications in addition to the cyclosporine.
LFTs today were significantly decreased from ___. ALT 80, AST
26, AP 315, Tbili 0.4.

report:
EXAMINATION:  CT abdomen and pelvis without IV contrast.

INDICATION:  ___ with cirrhosis presents with mechanical fall

TECHNIQUE:  Multidetector CT images of the abdomen and pelvis were acquired
without intravenous contrast. Non-contrast scan has several limitations in
detecting vascular and parenchymal organ abnormalities, including tumor
detection.
Oral contrast was not administered.
Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed and reviewed on PACS.

DOSE:  Total DLP (Body) = 914 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  None.

IMPRESSION:


1. No evidence of intra-abdominal hemorrhage.
2. Cirrhotic liver with ascites, splenomegaly, and varices.  Thickening of the
ascending colonic wall is likely due to portal colopathy.
3. Focal enlargement of the main portal vein with peripheral calcification,
which may represent a chronic portal vein thrombosis, however this is
difficult to assess on an unenhanced examination.  Correlation with ultrasound
or contrast-enhanced CT is recommended, if not done previously.

RECOMMENDATION(S):
Focal enlargement of the main portal vein with peripheral calcification, which
may represent a chronic portal vein thrombosis, however this is difficult to
assess on an unenhanced examination.  Correlation with ultrasound or
contrast-enhanced CT is recommended, if not done previously.

vein thrombosis on the unenhanced CT from earlier on the same day.  Evaluate
for portal vein thrombosis.

TECHNIQUE:  Limited and targeted color and spectral Doppler evaluation of the
right upper abdomen was performed.

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis without contrast dated ___,
earlier on the same day.
No prior abdominal ultrasound is available on PACS at the time of this
dictation.

IMPRESSION: 

Patent hepatic vasculature.  No thrombus detected.  The main portal vein
demonstrates hepatopetal flow.
